text: Patient: It wasn't really great in detail. Doctor: Okay, so this is the, this is the consent form for the MAP trial. So this is the MAP trial phase three, meaning that it's just more advanced and we're comparing it against placebo and it's a large trial. So I want you to take this home, I want you to read it, and I want you to think about it. I'll contact our research nurses too to see if you're eligible. And then we'll give you a call tomorrow and you can tell me. Yes, I think this is reasonable. Let's keep going. You can tell me- Patient: Trust me, I don’t have to wait until next week. Family Member: Trust me, he'll sign it right now. Patient: I’m serious. Family Member: I mean, he's ready to go. We kind of talked about it. Okay. Doctor: You know, so what were the discussion or what were you thinking or what were the discussions that you were having before? Family Member: Well, I was telling him about what N___ did for friend of mine and what he went through Doctor: Mm okay. Family Member: a lot of a prostrate clinical trials study also. Doctor: Oh okay. Family Member: So I went with him. You know, while he started the process, Doctor: Oh okay.

text: Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general. Doctor: Ehhhh -- Well it’s – uh. The immunotherapy’s targeted to the immune system, but it’s not targeted to your cancer. Again, it, too, is like chemotherapy, praying and hoping that it’s gonna attack your cancer. Patient: Uh-huh. Okay. Doctor: It definitely has less side effects than chemotherapy. It just has more risk because if it attacks you, then you can get into trouble faster. Patient: My hair will fall out again? Doctor: Nope. (Pause) Patient: Okay will it get curlier?

text: Patient: I, uh, I guess the one question that I had, um, reading the, the paperwork and then this conversation - You’re waiting until after the chemo and then four weeks after chemo before any spot radiation for any, any sites that have popped up. Why not treat the one spot now, that I’m, the, the rib? ‘Cuz you can’t operate there. And, I understand radiation pre-surgery on the prostate, probably not a really good thing to do and then have surgery. But, the rib - why not do the spot therapy? Doctor: Because the hormone’s gonna take care of that. The chemo is gonna take care of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The radiation is gravy. That’s the bow on top of the package. Patient: Gotcha, okay. So, it’s, it’s not a primary treatment then? Doctor: No. We’re going to everywhere the cancer is, whether we see it or we don’t see it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, you know, then based on sort of what we do see, we’re gonna sort of pinpoint that. Patient: Okay. Tallyho. Doctor: And, so, other thoughts or questions? So, typically, what we would do is I’m gonna give you a prescription for a pill drug today. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, you take it, you take it for thirty days and then you stop. Uh, in two weeks you come in and you get your first hormone shot. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
